Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Tissue-specific expression of recombinant TERT proteins in Telomerase-null medaka fish (Oryzia latipes)

POR.DRECONTENT:
The in vivo gene knock-in system using inverted terminal repeats from adeno-associatedvirus has been developed and implemented within a variety of aquatic species including medakafish (Oryzias latipes), zebrafish (Danio rerio), and several additional aquatic anaimals. Atransgene is integrated into the host genome through a recombination event facilitated byflanking sequences from the adeno-associated virus which provides for stable, Medelianinheritance to progeny. The transgene construct is introduced to the host organism bymicroinjection into the single cell stage. Simple detection of transgene expression is achieved byencoding for a fluorescent protein as a single open reading frame or bicistronic following theprimary reading frame following and an internal ribosome entry site. This system utilized alone,and in conjunction with additional in vivo, in vitro, and in situ techniques is a powerful tool forthe discovery of molecular mechanisms and for probing into the molecular underpinnings ofcellular function within a host aquatic animal model. These systems devised and modified atNational Taiwan University under the direction of Dr. Huai-Jen Tsai, will be established at byJoshua Podlevsky at Arizona State University under the direction of Dr. Julian Chen.

The α-actin promoter is muscle tissue specific, with high expression observed inzebrafish 2 days post fertilization with the highest levels of expression within the trunk of theanimal (figure 3, central and lower panels). The integration site of the genetic information intothe fish genome affects the GFP expression. Integration into a site of low transcription willresult in reduced GFP expression levels compared to a location of high transcription. Thus two animals with successful integrations of thegenetic material into the genome potentiallyhavediffering levels of GFP expression basedon the location of insertion into the genome.Additionally, the number of integrations intothe genome, via a single site, or across thewhole genome, will result in higher GFPexpression due to multiple copies eachexpressing. Genetics and moleculartechniques can be employed to determine if the genetic material was inserted into multiplelocations, multiple insertions into a singlesite, or the location of a single insertion into asingle site. However, the determination oflocation and number of copies is beyond thescope of the planned experimental proceduresand will be undertaken after the end of theprogram as a future work (figure 2, comparethe middle panels to the bottom panels).
